CactusTool.funcs module¶

This modular provided many useful functions needed by other modular.

CactusTool.funcs.ensure_list(obj)[source]¶

This function ensures that obj is a list. Typically used to convert a string to a list.

CactusTool.funcs.ensure_numpy_array(obj)[source]¶

This function ensures that obj is a numpy array. Typically used to convert scalar, list or tuple argument passed to functions using Cython.

CactusTool.funcs.fetch_all_file(path)[source]¶

Fetch all important file in path, especially .par, .asc, and .h5 file.

Parameters

path (str) – absolute path

Returns

file list with absolute path.

CactusTool.funcs.filter_file(files, file_style)[source]¶

Choose the file end with specified file_style

Parameters

  • path (list) – A list of file in absolute path.

  • file_style (str) –

    There are few file_style you can choose:

    • par: parameter file

    • scalar file

    • ASCII file

    • HDF5 file

    • checkpoints

CactusTool.funcs.rm_output_active(files)[source]¶

output-dddd-active/ is a copy from output-dddd/, so we remove these file in output-dddd-active/ to avoid duplicate.

Parameters

path (list) – A list of file in absolute path.

Returns

file list withnot the one in output-dddd-active

CactusTool.grid_data module¶

The CactusTool.grid_data module provides representations of data on uniform grids as well as for data on refined grid hirachies.

property Scalar¶

CactusTool.outputfile module¶

Carpet provides ASCII and HDF5-based output for Carpet. These I/O methods can output any type of CCTK grid variables (grid scalars, grid functions, and grid arrays of arbitrary dimension). The outputfile module provides most of the functionality of functions to deal with these different type of output file.

CactusTool.outputfile.HDF5_gf(file, slice)[source]¶

CactusTool.preview module¶

CactusTool.preview.hdf5_2d(X, Y, data, title=None, colormap='RdBu')[source]¶

Create a pseudocolor plot

Note

The dimensions of X and Y should be one greater than those of C. Alternatively, X, Y and C may have equal dimensions, in which case the last row and column of C will be ignored.

Parameters

  • X (array) – A 1-D array. They will be expanded as needed into the appropriate 2-D arrays, making a rectangular grid.

  • Y (array) – A 1-D array. They will be expanded as needed into the appropriate 2-D arrays, making a rectangular grid.

  • data (array) – A scalar 2-D array. The values will be color-mapped.

  • title (str) – Set figure title.

  • colormap (str) – A Colormap name. The colormap maps the C values to colors.

CactusTool.unit module¶

This module provides a class Units representing unit systems or unit conversions. All expressed in SI units.

CactusTool.visualize module¶

This module provides functions to plot different type of figure.

  • color_bar: color_bar()

  • 2-D scalar plot: imshow(), pcolormesh(), contour(), surface()

  • 2-D vector plot: vectors()

  • grid struct: grid_struct()

CactusTool.visualize.color_bar(image, **kwargs)[source]¶

Adds a colorbar with given axes.

Parameters

  • im – Which image object to use for the colorbar.

  • kwargs – Unknown keyword arguments are passed to plt.colorbar().

CactusTool.visualize.contour(ax, X, Y, Z, fill=True, contour_levels=10, line_levels=5, line_color='k', **kwargs)[source]¶

Draw contour lines or filled contours.

Parameters

  • ax – Which axes to use for the plot.

  • X, Y (array) – The coordinates of the values in Z. X and Y must both be 2-D with the same shape as Z (e.g. created via numpy.meshgrid())

  • Z (array) – 2D data to plot.

  • fill (bool) – draw contour lines or filled contours

  • contour_levels – if fill is True; contour_levels determines the number of the filled contours.

  • line_levels – if fill is True; line_levels determines the number of the lines.

  • line_color – if fill is True; line_color determines the color of the lines.

  • kwargs – Unknown keyword arguments are passed to ax.contour() or ax.contourf().

Returns

image object

>>> im = imshow(ax, X, Y, Z)
Only draw contour lines.
>>> im = contour(ax, x, y, Z, fill=True)
Draw contour lines and filled contours,
>>> im = contour(ax, x, y, Z, fill=True, contour_levels=10, line_levels=5)
Draw contour lines and filled contours, filled levels determined by contour_levels and line number determined by line_levels
>>> im = contour(ax, x, y, Z, fill=True, line_color='r')
line color determined by line_color
>>> im = contour(ax, x, y, Z, fill=True, cmap=plt.cm.bone)
filled color determined by cmap
>>> im = contour(ax, X, Y, Z, fill=True, alpha=0.5)
The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
>>> Zm = np.ma.masked_where(np.abs(Z) < 0.000001, Z)
>>> im = contour(ax, x, y, Zm, fill=False)
control the masked region.
>>> from matplotlib import ticker
>>> im = contour(ax, x, y, Z, locator=ticker.LogLocator(), fill=True)
log locator tells contourf to use a log scale
CactusTool.visualize.grid_struct()[source]¶

Plots grid structure.

CactusTool.visualize.imshow(ax, Z, axis_ticks=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot an array as an image. Loss coordinate information. This function return image object, you can add colorbar use color_bar().

If X and Y are each equidistant, imshow can be more convenient.

Parameters

  • ax – Which axes to use for the plot.

  • Z (array) – 2D data to plot.

  • axis_ticks (bool) – Whether turn on axis lines and labels.

  • kwargs – Unknown keyword arguments are passed to ax.imshow()

Returns

image object

Supported interpolation are [‘none’, ‘nearest’, ‘bilinear’, ‘bicubic’, ‘spline16’, ‘spline36’, ‘hanning’, ‘hamming’, ‘hermite’, ‘kaiser’, ‘quadric’, ‘catrom’, ‘gaussian’, ‘bessel’, ‘mitchell’, ‘sinc’, ‘lanczos’].

>>> im = imshow(ax, Z, axis_ticks=True)
turn on axis lines and labels.
>>> im = imshow(ax, Z, cmap='RdBu')
colormap name used to map scalar data to colors.
>>> im = imshow(ax, Z, alpha=0.5)
The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque).
>>> im = imshow(ax, Z, interpolation='nearest')
Interpolation method.
CactusTool.visualize.pcolormesh(ax, X, Y, Z, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a pseudocolor 2-D plot.

Parameters

  • ax – Which axes to use for the plot.

  • X, Y (array) – The coordinates of X and Y are bounds.

  • Z (array) – 2D data to plot.

  • kwargs – Unknown keyword arguments are passed to ax.pcolormesh().

Returns

image object

Note

If X, Y and Z have equal dimensions, the last value from the z array may be removed.

>>> im = pcolormesh(ax, x, y, Z)
Create a pseudocolor 2-D plot.
>>> Zm = np.ma.masked_where(np.abs(Z) < 0.0001, Z)
>>> im = pcolormesh(ax, x, y, Zm, shading='gouraud')
CactusTool.visualize.surface(ax, X, Y, Z, mesh=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a surface plot.

Parameters

  • ax – Which axes to use for the plot. ax is the 3D projection.

  • X, Y (array) – The coordinates of the values in Z. X and Y must both be 2-D with the same shape as Z (e.g. created via numpy.meshgrid())

  • Z (array) – 2D data to plot.

  • mesh (bool) – A mesh plot

  • kwargs – Unknown keyword arguments are passed to ax.contour() or ax.contourf().

Returns

image object

>>> fig = plt.figure()
>>> ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
>>> im = surface(ax, x, y, Z)
Create a surface plot.
>>> im = surface(ax, x, y, Z, cmap=plt.cm.YlGnBu_r)
A colormap for the surface patches.
>>> im = surface(ax, x, y, Z, mesh=True)
A mesh plot.
CactusTool.visualize.vectors(ax, X, Y, U, V, W=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot vectors in 2-D plot. The color of the arrows is its mod. ax.quiverkey() auto-scales the length of the arrows to a reasonable size.

Parameters

  • ax – Which axes to use for the plot.

  • X, Y (array) – X, Y define the arrow locations.

  • U, V, W (array) – 3-D vector have component (U, V, W). Default is 2-D vector (U,V)

  • kwargs – Unknown keyword arguments are passed to ax.quiverkey().

Returns

image object

>>> im = vectors(ax, x, y, U, V)
Plot a 2D field of vectors.
>>> im = vectors(ax, x, y, U, V, W)
Plot a 3D field of vectors in 2D plot.
